instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PM_S0_PGOOD: What is PM_S0_PGOOD?  PM_S0_PGOOD is created when CPUVR_PGOOD and ALL_SYS_PWRGD are present and branches off to become PM_PCH_PWROK. PM_S0_PGOOD and SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD are necessary to create SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK .
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD: What is CPUVR_PGOOD? CPU_VR_PGOOD Is a signal present when CPU_VR_EN is presenT. CPU_VR_PGOOD is a prerequisite along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD and PM_PCH_PWROK and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK which are necessary for the machine to turn on and boot..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A water damaged, doesn't turn on
threads.message:
Board was water damaged. Fixed a couple of parts to get ISL working. The rest I have cleaned with iso.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> -------------------------------- 12.56V
PP3V42 --------------------------------------- 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> ------------------------------------- 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> ----------------------------------- 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> ------------------------------ 3.3V
<SIGNAL>SMC_CLK32K</SIGNAL> ------------------------------ 1.7V
<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL> ------------------- 0.42V
<SIGNAL>PM_CLK32K_SUSCLK_R</SIGNAL> --------------- 1.7V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> ---------------------- 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> ---------------------------- 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> --------------------------- 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> ---------------------------- 3.42V

I'm using a genuine 60W charger. I could try another one I guess.

S4 rails are not present. Am I missing something?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A water damaged, doesn't turn on
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check if <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts.
No pulse at least at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A water damaged, doesn't turn on
threads.message: Yes check all that 2informaticos suggested. Also, check resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> you said there was liquid there

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A water damaged, doesn't turn on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> ---------- 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> ------- 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> -- 3.3V

I haven't triggered <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> only because I've found <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR> broken, along with its trace. (Even though I don't see how that would make prior stuff not work)

There is no pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.

[USER="1153"]JohnB8812[/USER] <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.56V. I've rebuilt the circuit around ISL. They all measure correct. including pins 17/18 and 27/28 Sorry I haven't written that explicitly what has been done.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A water damaged, doesn't turn on
threads.message:
"I haven't triggered <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL>"
Try and comment.
Check <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> reaction at the same moment when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A water damaged, doesn't turn on
threads.message: If you're 100% sure pins 17/18 and 27/28 measure 20.9 and 3.9 approximately, then yes next thing to try is <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL> does anything.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A water damaged, doesn't turn on
threads.message:
Got it to work. <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is back due to <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR> being corroded and messed up all necessary rails prior to <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.

Mark as solved please.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A water damaged, doesn't turn on
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR> is not involved in <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> generation.
In fact this signal should appear in the first moments of power sequence.
I bet it was pulsing and not maintained because of missing power good from VCORE power supply.

Be aware of wrong assumptions, is not the best way to learn...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A water damaged, doesn't turn on
threads.message:
I tried to catch some pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> as soon as the charger was connected, but didn't see anything. I tried 3 times.

As for <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR>, that is correct. It is not related in <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> generation, rather as input voltage for <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> which releases <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD</SIGNAL>, which goes to <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, creates <SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL>, responsible for creating <SIGNAL>SYS_PWROK_R</SIGNAL>, after <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR> it is <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>, and finally comes to CPU, which then releases <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.

Well, either my eyes are not seeing good or something, but you say that even without <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, there should be a pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> from CPU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A water damaged, doesn't turn on
threads.message:
CPU cannot get VCORE if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is not released first by PCH...
You may not see that signal pulsing when charger is connected.
But you can see that if manually trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal.
Better to use an o-scope to catch fast pulses...

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is used to enable S3 voltages.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> is used to enable S0 volatges.
